metadata.case_name: Fazilka Electric Supply Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income Tax

facts.text: On July 23, 1934, the then Government of the Punjab granted a license under s. 3 of Indian Electricity Act, 1910 to Harbhagwan Nanda and Harcharan Dass for generation and supply of electric energy in Fazilka.
Clause 9(1) of the license provided that option of purchase under s.7(1) Electricity Act exercisable after 15 years and every subsequent 10 years, with 20% addition for compulsory purchase.
In 1935, Fazilka Electric Supply Co. Ltd. (appellant) incorporated and acquired rights of the license.
Appellant carried on business for 15 years.
On July 23, 1949, Punjab Government exercised option and acquired undertaking for Rs. 374,000/-, excess over written down value (WDV).
For assessment year 1950-51, ITO computed excess over WDV not exceeding original cost minus WDV at Rs. 77,700/-, taxable u/s 10(2)(vii) IT Act 1922.
Appellant contended no part of excess taxable as compulsory acquisition, not voluntary sale u/s 10(2)(vii).
ITAT held against appellant, transaction a sale u/s 10(2)(vii).
Appellant moved ITAT for reference: Whether acquisition under s.7(1) Electricity Act and cl.9 license is sale u/s 10(2)(vii) IT Act.
ITAT referred to Punjab High Court in I.T.R. No. 18 of 1954; HC answered against appellant on April 24, 1959.
Appellant obtained certificate u/s 66A(2) IT Act, preferred appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and circumstances, and on true interpretation of s.7(1) Electricity Act and cl.9 Fazilka Electric License 1934, the Government acquisition is a sale u/s 10(2)(vii) IT Act 1922.

petitioner_arguments.text: Acquisition is compulsory, not sale involving mutual agreement or contract for transfer of property for price; s.10(2)(vii) IT Act not attracted.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.10(2)(vii) Indian Income-tax Act 1922; Sale of Goods Act definition implied

petitioner_arguments.text: s.7 Electricity Act provides compulsory acquisition independent of agreement.

respondent_arguments.text: Transaction is sale per contract; license grant process amounts to agreement with option to purchase.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.3, s.7, s.10 Indian Electricity Act 1910; Rules thereunder

court_reasoning.text: License process under Electricity Act and rules is contractual: applicant proposes draft with terms, govt approves/modifies, applicant accepts - constitutes contract with option to purchase.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Option per agreed periods in license; no compulsory acquisition independent of agreement.

court_reasoning.text: 'Compulsory purchase' in s.7 proviso allows agreed % addition to market value, not true compulsion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: All contract elements present: undertaking to sell on terms, consideration via license grant.

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly held license grant amounts to contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Sale pursuant to contract, not compulsory acquisition.

holdings.text: Acquisition under cl.9 license read with s.7 Electricity Act is a sale within meaning of s.10(2)(vii) IT Act; Rs.77,700 taxable as profits.

precedents_cited.relevance: Cited in context of contract elements, though not detailed

statutes_cited.name: Indian Electricity Act, 1910
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs license grant and option of purchase; interpreted as contractual

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Taxability of excess on sale of assets as profits; reference to HC

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court, holding the acquisition a sale u/s 10(2)(vii) IT Act; Rs.77,700 taxable as profits. Unnecessary to consider if compulsory sale attracts provision.

key_quotes.text: "the scheme of the Electricity Act as indicated by the relevant provisions thereof and the rules made thereunder, shows beyond any doubt that the option of purchase is the result of a mutual agreement between the parties"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning that transaction contractual, not compulsory

key_quotes.text: "a license granted by the Government in such circumstances amounts to a contract between the parties."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: High Court observation adopted; defines nature of license

key_quotes.text: "There was a sale in the present case of the building, machinery and plant within the meaning of cl. (vii) of s. 10(2) of the Income-tax Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct holding resolving the referred question
